title: What is solute solvent interaction? - Quora

response.answer_text: Solute+ solvent → solution (a homogeneous mixture). Remember like dissolves like. In general polar solvent dissolves polar solutes and non-polar solvents dissolve non- polar solutes. For example 1. Water is a polar solvent and dissolves ionic salt (polar) [Polarity refers to the separation of charges including partial charges within the molecule.]  Transfer of electron leads to the formation of ions. Oppositely charged ions are held together by strong electrostatic force of attraction i.e. ionic bond if formed.  Molecules form crystals.  Water is polar solvent. When sodium chloride is dissolved in water – first the attraction force between the molecules are weakened. Then the ions are surrounded by water molecules as shown. 2.Non-polar solvents dissolve non-polar substances such as oils, fats, greases. Examples of non-polar solvents: carbon tetrachloride (CCl4), benzene (C6H6), and diethyl ether ( CH3CH2OCH2CH3), hexane (CH3(CH2)4CH3), methylene chloride (CH2Cl2). Hope this helps

Solute–solvent and solvent–solvent interactions have been studied in fifteen pure solvents and seven binary aqueous mixtures by monitoring the solubility of a dye in the solvents. The standard Gibbs energy of solvation, as given by log s, where s is the solubility has been found to depend on various modes of solute–solvent interaction and also on the Hildebrand solubility parameter representing the cohesive energy density (solvent–solvent interaction) of solvent. In all the binary mixtures the value of log s has been found to deviate from the average of log s values in component pure solvents weighted with respect to their mole fractions. A dimensionless quantity has been defined to represent the deviation of the observed log s values from the mole fraction average. Results have been explained in terms of various modes of solvation interaction.

When a solute is dissolved in a solvent, there takes place few changes in solute and solvent. The intermolecular bonding between the solute particles and solvent particles like, Vander Waals forces, dipole-dipole interaction,etc. are disturbed and broken and a new bond between a solute and a solvent particle is formed. This is energy dependent. If energy of disturbing the solute and solvent bonding is lower than the energy needed for interaction between a solute and a solvent particle, then the solute does not completely interact and remain separate . If it is sufficient for new interactions, then there will interaction between the solute and solvent.
